nodes.text: Machine learning algorithms can be used to predict stock market values and help investors make better buy/sell decisions
This paper uses a Systematic Literature Review (SLR) methodology to collect and synthesize prior research on machine learning for stock prediction
The review frames three research questions about the need for prediction, relevant attributes/factors, and ML algorithms used for stock prediction
Prior research demonstrates multiple ML algorithms (SVM, neural networks, linear regression, genetic algorithms, KNN, random forest) have been applied to stock prediction
Conclusion: Accurate ML-based stock prediction can increase investor profit and inform buy/sell timing, but prediction remains challenging
Inclusion criteria: papers in English, fully available, and relevant to stock market prediction; excluded papers not meeting these criteria
Search process: initial corpus of 550 papers from digital libraries (Elsevier, ACM, IEEE, Google Scholar) filtered by title, abstract, then full text, yielding 45 included papers
Quality assessment: evaluated contribution of each paper's authors before inclusion to ensure good quality of reviewed studies
RQ1 finding: Stock market prediction is necessary because investors seek profit and to avoid losses; accurate prediction supports better investment timing

RQ2 finding: Useful predictive attributes include market history, news/events, public mood, commodity prices (oil, gold, silver), interest rates, foreign exchange, and macroeconomic factors (consumer spending, unemployment, inflation)
RQ3 finding: Commonly applied ML algorithms in reviewed studies include linear regression, neural networks, support vector machines, genetic algorithms, k-nearest neighbor, and random forest
Evidence: Multiple studies applied SVM and reported better performance than some classification methods for next-day stock movement prediction
Evidence: Neural network studies used price history and social media/news inputs and showed improved prediction when combined with event knowledge or text features

Evidence: Reported accuracies vary: Qian and Rasheed reported 65% accuracy with multiple classifiers, a study reported 64% with random forest, and another source cited random forest achieving 83% in some contexts
Limitation/evidence: Stock market prediction is challenging due to dynamic changes and multiple external events influencing prices, making consistent high accuracy difficult
